editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Greene's tu quoque, or, the city gallant. As it hath been divers times acted by the Queen's majesty's servants, written by Io. Cooke gent.
Printed at London for John trundle. 1614.

div.head: To the reader.
div.p: To gratulate the love and memory of my worthy friend the author, and my entirely beloved fellow, the actor, I could not choose being in the way just when this play was to be published in Pr●ut, but to prefix some token of my affection to either in the frontispiece of the book. For the gentleman that wrote it, his poem itself can better speak his praise, than any oratory from me. Nor can I tell whether this work was divulged with his consent or no: but howsoever, since it hath passed the test of the stage with so general an applause, pity it were but it should likewise have the honour of the press. As for master green, all that I will speak of him (And that without flattery) is this (If I were worthy to censure) there was not an actor of his nature in his time of better ability in performance of what he undertook; more applaudent by the audience, of greater grace at the court, or of more general love in the city, and so with this brief character of his memory, I commit him to his rest.

div.head: Upon the death of Thomas Greene.

lg.l: How fast bleak autumn changeth Flora's dye,
What yesterday was (Green) now's sear and dry.

div.head: Greene's tu quoque.
div.stage: A mercer's shop discovered, Gartred working in it, Spendall walking by the shop: m balance walking over the stage: after him Longfield and Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Francis.
sp.p: What lack you sir? fair stuffs, or velvets?

sp.speaker: Ball.
sp.p: Good morrow Frank.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Good morrow master balance.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Save you master Longfield.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And you sir, what business draws you towards this end o'th town?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Faith no great serious affairs, only a stirring humour to walk, and partly to see the beauties of the city; but it may be you can instruct me: pray whose shop's this?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Why 'tis will Rash's fathers, a man that you are well acquainted with. Enter a wench with a basket of linen

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: As with yourself; and is that his sister?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Marry is it sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pray let us walk, I would behold her better.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Buy some coifs, handkerchiefs, or very good bonelace mistress.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Will you buy any handkerchiefs, sir?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes, have you any fine ones?

sp.speaker: Wench
sp.p: I'll show you choice, please you look sir?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: How now! what news?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Mistress Tickleman has sent you a letter, and expects your company at night, and entreats you to send her an angel, whether you can come, or whether you can not. He reads.

sp.speaker: Spend.

body.p: Sweet rascal! if your love be as earnest as your protestation, you will meet me this night at supper, you know the rendezvouses, there will be good company, a noise of choice fiddlers, a fine boy with an excellent voice, very good songs and bawdy; and which is more, I do purpose myself to be exceeding merry: but if you come not, I shall pout myself sick, and not eat one bit tonight.

closer.signed: Your continual close friend, Nan tickleman.

sp.p: I pray send me an angel by this bearer, whether ye can come, or whether ye cannot. What's the price of these two?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Half a crown in truth, sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Hold thee, there's an angel, and commend me to my delight, tell her I will not fail her, though I lose my freedom by't. Exit wench.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: I thank you sir; buy any fine handkerchiefs?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: You are taken sir extremely, what's the object?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: She's wondrous fair.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Nay, and your thoughts be on wenching I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: You shall not be so unfriendly, pray assist me; we'll to the shop and cheapen stuffs or satins.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: What lack you gentlemen? fine stuffs, velvets, or satins? pray come near.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Let me see a good satin.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You shall sir, what colour?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Faith I am indifferent, what colour most affects you lady?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Without offence (Fair creature) I demand it.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Sir, I believe it, but I never did
Tie my affection unto any colour.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: But my affection (Fairest) is fast tied
Unto the crimson colour of your cheek.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You relish too much courtier, sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What's the price of this?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Fifteen indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: You set a high rate on't, it had need be good.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Good! if you find a better i'th town, I'll give you mine for nothing: if you were my own brother, I'd put it into your hands, look upon't, 'tis close wrought, and has an excellent glass.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Ay, I see't.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Pray sir come into the next room; I'll show you that of a lower price shall (Perhaps) better please you.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: This fellow has an excellent tongue, sure he was brought up in the exchange.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Will you come in sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: No, 'tis no matter, for I mean to buy none.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Pre thee walk in, what you bargain for, I'll discharge.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Say so; fall to your work, I'll be your chapman.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why do you say I flatter? Exeunt Spend. Long.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Why? you do;
And so do all men when they women woo.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Who looks on heaven, and not admires the work?
Who views a well cut diamond, does not praise
The beauty of the stone? if these deserve
The name of excellent, I lack a word
For thee which merit'st more,
More than the tongue of man can attribute.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: This is pretty poetry, good fiction this: sir, I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Leave with me first some comfort.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: What would you crave?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: That which I fear you will not let me have.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You do not know my bounty; say what 'tis.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No more (Fair creature) then a modest kiss.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: If I should give you one, would you refrain, on that condition, ne'er to beg again.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I dare not grant to that.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Then't seems you have,
Though you get nothing, a delight to crave,
One will not hurt my lip, which you may take,
Not for your love, but for your absence' sake. So farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O fare thee well (Fair regent of my soul)
Never let ill sit near thee, unless it come
To purge itself; be as thou ever seemst,
An angel of thy sex, born to make happy
The man that shall possess thee for his bride.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p: Will you have it for thirteen shillings and six pence? I'll fall to as low a price as I can, because I'll buy your custom.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: How now man! what! entranced?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Good sir, ha' you done?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes faith, I think as much as you, and 'tis just nothing: where's the wench?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: She's here sir, here.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Uds pity! unbutton man, thou'lt stifle her else.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nay good sir, will you go?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: With all my heart, I stay but for you.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p: Do you hear sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What say?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Will you take it for thirteen?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Not a penny more than I bid. Ex. Ger. and Long.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Why then say you might have had a good bargain; where's this boy to make up the wares? here's some ten pieces opened, and all to no purpose. Enter boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O Frank ▪ shut up shop, shut up shop.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Shut up shop, boy, why?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
My master is come from the court knighted, and bid
us, for he says he will have the first year of the reign of his knighthood kept holiday; here he comes. Enter sir Lionell.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: God give your worship joy, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir lionel
sp.p: O Francke ▪ I have the worship now in the right kind, the sword of knighthood sticks still upon my shoulders, and I feel the blow in my purse, it has cut two leather bags asunder; but all's one, honour must be purchased: I will give over my city coat, and betake myself to the court jacket; as for trade, I will deal in't no longer, I will seat thee in my shop, and it shall be thy care to ask men what they lack, my stock shall be summed up, and I will call thee to an account for it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: My service sir, never deserved so much,
Nor could I ever hope so large a bounty
Could spring out of your love.

sp.speaker: Sir lionel
sp.l: That's all one,
I do love to do things beyond men's hopes,
Tomorrow I remove into the strand,
There for this quarter dwell, the next at Fulham:
He that hath choice, may shift, the whilst shalt thou
Be master of this house, and rent it free.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Sir lionel
sp.p: Today I'll go dine with my lord mayor: tomorrow with the sheriffs, and next day with the aldermen, I will spread the ensign of my knighthood over the face of the city, which shall strike as great a terror to my enemies, as ever Tamberlaine to the Turks.

lg.l: Come Frank, come in with me, and see the meat,
Upon the which my knighthood first shall eat. Ex: omnes.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p:
There is a devil has haunted me these three years, in likeness of an usurer, a fellow that in all his life never ●at three groat loaves out of his own purse, nor never warmed him but at other men's fires, never saw a joint of mutton in his own house these four and twenty years, but always cozened the poor prisoners, for he always bought his victuals
out of the almsbasket, and yet this rogue now feeds upon capons which my tenants sent him out of the country; he is landlord forsooth over all my possessions: well, I am spent, and this rogue has consumed me; I dare not walk abroad to see my friends, for fear the sergeants should take acquaintance of me: my refuge is Ireland, or Virginia; necessity cries out, and I will presently to Westchester. Enter Bubble.how now! Bubble hast thou packed up all thy things? our parting time is come: nay pray thee do not weep.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Affection sir will burst out.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Thou hast been a faithful servant to me, go to thy uncle, he'll give thee entertainment, tell him upon the stony rock of his merciless heart my fortunes suffer shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I will tell him he is an usuring rascal, and one that would do the commonwealth good, if he were hanged.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Which thou hast cause to wish for, thou art his heir, my affectionate bubble.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: But master, wherefore should we be parted?

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Because my fortunes are desperate, thine are hopeful.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why but whither do you mean to go master?

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Why to sea.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: To sea! Lord bless us, methinks I hear of a tempest already, but what will you do at sea?

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Why as other gallants do that are spent, turn pirate.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: O master! have the grace of Wapping before your eyes, remember a high tide, give not your friend's cause to wet their handkerchiefs: nay master, I'll tell you a better course than so, you and I will go and rob mine uncle; if we scape, we'll domineer together, if we be taken, we'll be hanged together at Tyburn, that's the warmer gallows of the two.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: By your leave sir, whereabouts dwells one m. bubble?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Do you hear, my friend, do you know m. bubble if you do see him?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: No in truth do I not.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What is your business with master bubble?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Marry sir, I come with welcome news to him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Tell it, my friend, I am the man.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: May I be assured sir, that your name is master bubble?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I tell thee, honest friend, my name is master bubble, master Bartholomew bubble.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Why then sir, you are heir to a million, for your uncle the rich usurer is dead.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Pray thee honest friend, go to the next haberdashers, and bid him send me a new melancholy hat, and take thou that for thy labour.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: I will sir. Exit.

div.stage: Enter another messenger hastily, and knocks.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Umh, umh, umh.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I would the news were true; see how my little bubble is blown up with't!

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Do you hear, my friend, for what do you knock there?

sp.speaker: 2. Messenger
sp.p: Marry sir, I would speak with the worshipful master bubble.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: The worshipful! and what would you do with the worshipful master bubble? I am the man.

sp.speaker: 2. Messenger
sp.p: I cry your worship mercy then, master Thong the beltmaker sent me to your worship, to give you notice, that your uncle is dead, and that you are his only heir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Thy news is good, and I have looked for't long,
Thanks unto thee, my friend, and goodman thong.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Certainly, this news is true: for see another, by this light his scrivener! now m. Blank, whither away so fast?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Master stains, God save you, where is your man?

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Why look you sir, do you not see him?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: God save the right worshipful master bubble; I bring you heavy news with a light heart.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I am your worships poor scrivener.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: He is an honest man it seems, for he has both his ears.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p:
I am one that your worship's uncle committed some
trust in for the putting out of his money, and I hope I shall have the putting out of yours.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: The putting out of mine! would you have the putting out of money?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Yea sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No sir, I am old enough to put out my own money.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I have writings of your worships.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: As thou lovest thy profit, hold thy tongue, thou and I will confer.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Do you hear, my friend, can you tell me when, and how my uncle died?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Yes sir, he died this morning, and he was killed by a butcher?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How! by a butcher?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Yes indeed sir, for going this morning into the market, to cheapen meat, he fell down stark dead, because a butcher asked him four shillings for a shoulder of mutton.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: How stark dead! And could not aqua vitae fetch him again?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: No sir, nor rosa solis neither, and yet there was trial made of both.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: I shall love aqua vitae et rosa solis the better while I live.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Will it please your worship to accept of my poor service, you know my case is desperate, I beseech you that I may feed upon your bread, though it be of the brownest, and drink of your drink though it be of the smallest, for I am humble in body, and dejected in mind, and will do your worship as good service for forty shillings a year, as another shall for 3. pounds.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I will not stand with you for such a matter, because you have been my master, but otherwise, I will entertain no man without some knights or lady's letter for their behaviour, Gervase I take it is your Christen name.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Yes if it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Well Gervase, be a good servant, and you shall find me a dutiful master: and because you have been a gentleman, I will entertain you for my tutor in behaviour; conduct me to my palace. Exeunt omnes.

div.stage: Enter Geraldine as in his study reading.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: As little children love to play with fire ▪
and will not leave till they themselves do burn,
So did I fondly dally with desire:
Until love's flames grew hot, I could not turn,
Nor well avoid; but sigh and sob, and mourn
As children do, whenas they feel the pain,
Till tender mother kiss them whole again.
Fie, what unsavoury stuff is this? but she,
Whose mature judgement can distinguish things,
Will thus conceit; tales that are harshest told,
Have smoothest meanings, and to speak are bold:
It is the firstborn sonnet of my brain,
We sucked a white leaf from my black-lipped pen
So sad employment,Enter Will rash and Long field.
Yet the dry paper drinks it up as deep,
As if it flowed from Petrarch's cunning quill.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: How now! what have we here, a sonnet and a satire coupled together like my lady's dog and her monkey; as little children etc.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pre thee away, by the deepest oath that can be sworn, thou shalt not read it, by our friendship I conjure thee, pray thee let go.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Now in the name of Cupid, what wantest thou, a pigeon, a dove, a mate, a turtle, dost love foul, ha?
O no, she's fairer thrice than is the Queen,
Whom beauteous Venus called is by name, pray thee let me know what she is thou lovest, that I may shunae her, if I should chance to meet her.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Why I'll tell you sir what she is, if you do not know.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: No not I, I protest.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Why 'tis your sister.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: How! my sister?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes, your eldest sister.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Now God bless the man, he had better choose a wench that has been born and bred in an alley, her tongue is a perpetual motion, thought is not so swift as it is; and for pride, the woman that had her ruff poked by the devil, is but a Puritan to her, thou couldst never have fastened thy affection on a worse subject, she'll flout faster than a court-waiting woman
in progress, any man that comes in the way of honesty does she set her mark upon, that is, a villainous left; for she is a kind of poetess, and will make ballads upon the calves of your legs: I pray thee let her alone, she'll never make a good wife for any man unless it be a leather dresser; for perhaps he, in time, may turn her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Thou hast a privilege to utter this,
But by my life my own blood could not scape
A chastisement for thus profaning her,
Whose virtues sits above men's calumnies,
Had mine own brother spoke thus liberally,
My fury should have taught him better manners.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: No more words as you fear a challenge.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: I may tell thee in thine ear, I am glad to hear what I do; I pray God send her no worse husband, nor he no worse wife: do you hear love, will you take your cloak and rapier, and walk abroad into some wholesome air? I do much fear thy infection, good council I see will do no good on thee, but pursue the end, and to thy thoughts, I'll prove a faithful friend.

div.stage: Enter Spendall, Nan Tickleman, sweat man, pursenet, and a drawer.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Here's a spacious room to walk in, sirrah set down the candle, and fetch us up a quart of ipocras, and so we'll part.

sp.speaker: Sweatman
sp.p: Nay faith son, we'll have a pottle, let's ne'er be covetous in our young days.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A pottle sirrah, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Yes sir, you shall.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: How now wench! how dost?

sp.speaker: Tickle.
sp.p: Faith I am somewhat sick, yet I should be well enough if I had a new gown.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Why here's my hand, within these three days thou shalt have one.

sp.speaker: Sweatman
sp.p: And will you (Son) remember me for a new forepart, by my troth, my old one is worn so bare, I am ashamed anybody should see't.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Why, did I ever fail of my promise?

sp.speaker: Sweatman
sp.p: No in sincerity didst thou not. Enter drawer.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Here's a cup of rich ipocras.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Here sister, mother, and master pursnet; nay good sir, be not so dejected, for by this wine, tomorrow I will send you stuff for a new suit, and as much as shall line you a cloak clean through.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I thank you, and shall study to deserve.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Here boy, fill, and hang that eurmogin that's good for nobody but himself.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Heroickly spoken by this candle, 'tis pity thou wert not made a lord.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A lord! by this light I do not think but to be lord mayor of London before I die, and have three pageants carried before me, besides a ship and an unicorn; prentices may pray for that time, for whensoever it happens, I will make another Shrove-tuesday for them. Enter drawer.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Young master rash has sent you a quart of Maligo.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: M: rash! 'zounds how does he know I am here?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Nay, I know not sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Know not! it comes through you and your rascally glib-tongued companions, 'tis my master's son, a fine gentleman he is, and a boon companion, I must go so him. Exit Spend.

sp.speaker: Sweatman
sp.p: Boy, fill us a cup of your maligo, we'll drink to m. Spendall in his absence, there's not a finer spirit of a citizen within the walls, here master pursnet you shall pledge him.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I'll not refuse it were it puddle: by Styx hs is a bountiful gentleman, and I shall report him so: here m Tickleman, shall I charge you?

sp.speaker: Tickl●.
sp.p: Do your worst sergeant, I'll pledge my young Spendall a whole sea, as they say, fa la la la la, would the music were here again, I do begin to be wanton, ipocras sirrah, and a dry biscuit; here bawd, a carouse.

sp.speaker: Sweatman
sp.p: Bawd! I'faith you begin to grow light ith' head, I pray, no more such words, for if you do, I shall grow into distempers.

sp.speaker: Tickle.
sp.p:
Distempers! hang your distempers, be angry with
me and thou dar'st, I pray, who feeds you, but I? who keeps the featherbeds from the brokers, but I? 'tis not your sausage face, thick clouted cream rampallion at home, that snuffles in the nose like a decayed bagpipe.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Nay, sweet mistress tickleman, be concordant, reverence antiquity.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Save you, sweet creatures of beauty, save you: how now old Belzebub, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Sweatman
sp.p: Belzebub! Belzebub in thy face.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Nay, good words mistress Swearman, he's a young gallant, you must not weigh what he says.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: I would my lamentable complaining lover had been here, here had been a supersede as for his melancholy, and i'faith Frank I am glad my father has turned over his shop to thee, I hope I, or any friend of mine, shall have so much credit with thee, as to stand in thy books for a suit of satin.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: For a whole piece, if you please, any friend of yours shall command me to the last remnant.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why God a mercy Francke, what, shall's to dice?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Dice or drink, here's forty crowns, as long as that will last, any thing.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why there spoke a gingling boy.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A pox of money, 'tis but rubbish, and he that hoards it up, it but a scavenger: if there be cards ith' house, let's go to primero.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Primero! why I thought thou hadst not been so much gamester as to play at it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Gamester (To say truth) I am none, but what is it I will not be in good company? I will fit myself to all humours, I will game with a gamester, drink with a drunkard, be civil with a citizen, fight with a swaggerer, and drab with a whoremaster.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: An excellent humour i'faith.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: 'Zounds what have we here?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A land porpoise, I think.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: This is no angry, nor no roaring boy, but a blustering boy; now Aeolus defend us, what puffs are these?

sp.speaker: Swaggerer
sp.p: I do smell a whore.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: O gentlemen, give him good words, he's one of the roaring boys.

sp.speaker: Swaggerer
sp.p: Rogue.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Swaggerer
sp.p: Take my cloak, I must unbuckle, my pickled oysters work; puff, puff.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Puff, puff.

sp.speaker: Swaggerer
sp.p: Dost thou retort, in opposition stand.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Out you swaggering rogue, 'zounds I'll kick him out of the room. Beates him away.

sp.speaker: Tickle.
sp.p: Out alas! their naked tools are out,

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Fear not (Sweet heart;) come along with me.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Thrice happy days they were, and too soon gone,
Whenas the heart was coupled with the tongue,
And no deceitful flattery or guile:
Hung on the lover's tear-commixed smile:
Could women learn but that imperiousness,
By which men use to stint our happiness,
When they have purchased us for to be theirs,
By customary sighs and forced tears,
To give us bits of kindness lest we faint,
But no abundance, that we ever want,
And still are begging; which too well they know
Endears affection, and doth make it grow:
Had we these sleights, how happy were we then,
That we might glory over lovesick men?
But arts we know not; nor have any skill,
To feign a sour look to a pleasing will,Enter joys.
Nor couch a secret love in show of hate:
but if we like, must be compassionate;
Yet I will strive to bridle and conceal,
The hid affection which my heart doth feel.

sp.speaker: Joyce
sp.p: Now the boy with the bird-bolt be praised: nay faith sister forward, was an excellent passion, come let's hear, what is he? if he be a proper man, and have a black eye, a smooth chin, and a curled pair, take him wench, if my father will not consent, run away with him, I'll help to convey you.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You talk strangely sister.

sp.speaker: Joyce
sp.p: Sister, sister, dissemble not with me, though you do mean to dissemble with your lover, though you have protested to conceal your affection; by this tongue you shall not, for I'll discover all as soon as I know the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Discover, what will you discover?

sp.speaker: Joyce
sp.p: Marry, enough I'll warrant thee, first and foremost, I'll tell him thou readest love-passions in print, and speakest every morning without book to thy lookingglass; next, that thou never sleepest, till an hour after the bell man; that as soon as thou art asleep, thou art in a dream, and in a dream thou art the kindest and comfortablest bedfellow for kissings and embracings; by this hand, I can not rest for thee, but our father. —

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.p: How now! what are you two consulting on, on husbands? you think you lose time I am sure, but hold your own a little girls, it shall not be long ere I'll provide for you: and for you gartered, I have bethought myself already,

lg.l: Whirlpit the usurer is late deceased,
A man of unknown wealth, which he has left
Unto a provident kinsman as I hear,
That was once servant to that unthrift stains.
A prudent gentleman they say he is,
And (As I take it) called master bubble.

sp.speaker: Joyce
sp.l: Bubble!

sp.speaker: Lyonell
sp.l: Yes nimble-chaps, what say you to that?

sp.speaker: Joyce
sp.l: Nothing, but that I wish his Christen name were wa●er.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Sir, I'm at your disposing, but my mind
Stands not as yet towards marriage,
Were you so pleased I would a little longer
Enjoy the quiet of a single bed.

sp.speaker: Lyonell
sp.l: Here's the right trick of them all, let a man
Be motioned to 'em, they could be content
To lead a single life forsooth, when the harlotries
Do pine and run into diseases,
Eat chalk and oatmeal, cry and creep in corners,
Which are manifest tokens of their longings,
And yet they will dissemble. But gartered,
As you do owe me reverence, and will pay it,
Prepare yourself to like this gentleman,
Who can maintain thee in thy choice of gowns,
Of tires, of servants, and of costly jewels;
Nay for a need, out of his easy nature,
Mayest draw him to the keeping of a coach
For country; and caroche for London,
Indeed what mightst thou not.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, here's one come from master bubble, to invite you to the funeral of his uncle.

sp.speaker: Lyonell
sp.l: Thank the messenger, and make him drink,
Tell him I will not fail to wait the corse,
Yet stay, I will go talk with him myself:
Gartered, think upon what I have told you,
And let me er't be long receive your answer.

sp.speaker: Joyce
sp.p: Sister, sister.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: What say you sister?

sp.speaker: Joyce
sp.p: Shall I provide a cord?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: A cord! what to do?

sp.speaker: Joyce
sp.p:
Why to let thee out at the window; do not I know that thou wilt run away with the gentleman, for whom you
made the passion, rather than endure this same bubble, that my father talks of, 'twere good you would let me be of your council, lest I break the neck of your plot.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Sister, know I love thee,
And I'll not think a thought thou shalt not know;
I love a gentleman that answers me,
In all the rites of love as faithfully,
Has wooed me oft with sonnets, and with tears,
Yet I seem still to slight him. Experience tells,
The jewel that's enjoyed is not esteemed,
Things hardly got, are always highest deemed.

sp.speaker: Joyce
sp.p: You say well sister, but it is not good to linger out too long, continuance of time will take away any man's stomach i'th world; I hope the next time that he comes to you, I shall see him.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You shall.

sp.speaker: Joyce
sp.p: Why go to then, you shall have my opinion of him, if he deserve thee, thou shalt delay him no longer; for if you can not find in your heart to tell him you love him, I'll sigh it out for you; come, we little creatures must help one another.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: How cheerfully things look in this place,
'Tis always springtime here, such is the grace
And potency of her who has the bliss,
To make it still Elysium where she is:
Nor doth the King of flames in's golden fires,
After a tempest answer men's desires,
Whenas he casts his comfortable beams,
Over the flowery fields and silver streams,
As her illustrate beauty strikes in me,
And wraps my soul up to felicity.

sp.speaker: Joyce
sp.p: Do you hear sir?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Why sister, what will you do?

sp.speaker: Joyce
sp.p:
By my maidenhead, an oath which I ne'er took in vain, either go down and comfort him, or I'll call him up,
and disclose all: what, will you have no mercy? but let a proper man, that might spend the spirit of his youth upon yourself, fall into a consumption, for shame sister.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You're the strangest creature, what would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Marry, I would have you go to him, take him by the hand, and gripe him, say you're welcome, I love you with all my heart, you are the man must do the feat, and take him about the neck, and kiss upon the bargain.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Fie how you talk, 'tis mere immodesty,
The commonest strumpet would not do so much.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Marry the better, for such as are honest,
Should still do what the common strumpet will not:
Speak, will you do it?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: I'll lose his company for ever first.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: Do you hear sir? here's a gentlewoman would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Why sister, pray sister.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: One that loves you with all her heart, yet is ashamed to confess it.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Good sister hold your tongue, I will go down to him.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: Do not jest with me, for by this hand I'll either get him up, or go down myself, and read the whole history of your love to him.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: If you'll forbear to call, I will go down.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: Let me see your back then, and hear you? do not use him scurvily you were best; unset all your tyrannical looks, and bid him lovingly welcome, or as I live, I'll stretch out my voice again; uds foot, I must take some pains I see, or we shall never have this gear cotton: but to say truth, the fault is in my melancholy Monsieur, for if he had but half so much spirit, as he has flesh, he might ha' boarded her by this. But see, yonder she marches; now a passion of his side of half an hour long, his hat is off already, as if he were begging one poor pennyworth of kindness. Enter Gart.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Shall I presume (Fair mistress) on your hand to lay my unworthy lip?

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: Fie upon him, I am ashamed to hear him, you shall have a country fellow at a maypole, go better to his work: he had need to be constant, for he is able to spoil as many maids as he shall fall in love withal.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Sir, you profess love unto me, let me entreat you it may appear but in some small request.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Let me know it (Lady) and I shall soon effect it.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: But for this present to forbear this place,
Because my father is expected here.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I am gone lady.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: Do you hear sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Did you call?

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: Look up to the window.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What say you gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Nay pray sir go, it is my sister calls to hasten you.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: I call to speak with you, pray stay a little.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: The gentlewoman has something to say to me.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: She has nothing, I do conjure you, as you love me, stay not. Exit Joyce.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: The power of magic can not fasten me, I am gone.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Good sir, look back no more, what voice ere call you,
Imagine, going from me, you were coming,
And use the same speed, as you love my safety. Exit Ger.
Wild witted sister, I have prevented you,
I will not have my love yet opened to him,
By how much longer 'tis ere it be known,Enter Joyce.
By so much dearer 'twill be when 'tis purchased:
But I must use my strength to stop her journey,
For she will after him: and see, she comes;
Nay sister, you are at furthest.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: Let me go you were best, for if you wrestle with me I shall throw you, passion, come back, fool, lover, turn again, and kiss your belly full;
sp.l: For here she is will stand you, do your worst:
Will you let me go?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Yes, if you'll stay.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: If I stir a foot, hang me, you shall come together of yourselves, and be naught, do what you will, for if 'Ere I trouble myself again, let me want help in such a case when I need.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Nay but pray thee sister be not angry.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: I will be angry, udsfoot, I cannot endure such foolery, ay, two bashful fools that would couple together, and yet ha' not the faces.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Nay pray thee sweet sister.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: Come, come, let me go, birds that want the use of reason and speech, can couple together in one day, and yet you that have both, cannot conclude in twenty.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Why what good would it do you to tell him?

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: Do not talk to me, for I am deaf to any thing you say, go weep and cry.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Nay but sister. Exeunt ambo.

div.stage: Enter stains, and a drawer with wine.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Drawer, bid them make haste at home,
Tell them they are coming from church.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: I will sir. Exit drawer.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
That I should live to be a servingman, a fellow which scalds his mouth with another man's porridge, brings up meat for other men's bellies, and carries away the bones for his own, changes his clean trencher for a foul one, and is glad of it, and yet did I never live so merry a life, when I was my master's master, as now I do, being man to my man, and I will stand to't for all my former speeches, a servingman lives a better life than his master, and thus I prove it; the saying is, the nearer the bone the sweeter the flesh: then must the servingman needs eat the sweeter flesh, for he always picks the bones. And again the proverb says, the deeper the sweeter: there has the servingman the vantage again, for he drinks still in the bottom of the pot, he fills his belly, and never
asks what's to pay? wears broadcloth, and yet dares walk Watlingstreet, without any fear of his draper: and for his colour, they are according to the season, in the summer he is apparelled (For the most part) like the heavens, in blue, in the winter, like the earth, in freeze.
sp.stage: Enter Bubble, sir Lionell, and Long-field and Sprinckle.

lg.l: But see, I am prevented in my encomium,
I could have maintained this theme these two hours.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Well, God rest his soul, he's gone, and we must all follow him

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Ay, ay, he's gone sir Lionell, he's gone.

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.p: Why though he be gone, what then? 'tis not you that can fetch him again, with all your cunning, it must be your comfort, that he died well.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Truly and so it is, I would to God I had e'en another uncle that would die no worse; surely I shall weep again, if I should find my handkercher.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: How now! what, are these onions?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Ay, ay, sir Lyonell, they are my onions, I thought to have had them roasted this morning for my cold: Gervase you have not wept today, pray take your onions gentlemen, the remembrance of death is sharp, therefore there is a banquet within to sweeten your conceits: I pray walk in gentlemen, walk you in, you know I must needs be melancholy, and keep my chamber, Gervase, usher them into the banquet.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I shall sir, please you sir Lyonell.

sp.speaker: Lyonell
sp.l: Well master bubble, we'll go in and taste of your bounty.
In the mean time, you must be of good cheer.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: If grief take not away my stomach,
I will have good cheer I warrant you sprinkle.

sp.speaker: Sprin.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Had the women puddings to their dole?

sp.speaker: Sprin.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: And how did they take them?

sp.speaker: Sprin.
sp.p: Why with their hands, how should they take 'em?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: O thou Hercules of ignorance! I mean, how were they satisfied?

sp.speaker: Sprin.
sp.p: By my troth sir, but so so, and yet some of them had two.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: O insatiable women! whom two puddings would not satisfy, but vanish sprinkle; bid your fellow Gervase come hither:Exit sprinkle.

lg.l: And off my mourning robes, grief to the grave,
For I have gold, and therefore will be brave:
In silks I'll rattle it of every colour,
And when I go by water, scorn a sculler,
In black carnation velvet I will cloak me,Enter stai●es.
And when men bid God save me, cry tu quoque:
It is needful a gentleman should speak Latin sometimes, is it not Gervase?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: O very graceful sir, your most accomplished gentlemen are known by it.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Why then will I make use of that little I have,
Upon times and occasions, here Gervase, take this bag,
sp.p: And run presently to the mercers, buy me seven ell, of horse flesh coloured taffeta, nine yards of yellow satin, and eight yards of orange tawny velvet; then run to the tailors, the haberdashers, the sempsters, the cutlers, the perfumers, and to all trades whatsoe'er that belong to the making up of a gentleman; and amongst the rest, let not the barber be forgotten: and look that he be an excellent fellow, and one that can snack his fingers with dexterity.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I shall fit you sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Do so good Gervase, it is time my beard were corrected, for it is grown so saucy, as it begins to play with my nose.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Your nose sir must endure it: for it is in part the fashion.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Is it in fashion? why then my nose shall endure it, let it tickle his worst.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why now you're ith' right sir, if you will be a true gallant, you must bear things resolute, as this sir, if you be at an ordinary, and chance to lose your money at play, you must not fret and fume, tear cards, and fling away dice, as your ignorant gamester, or country-gentleman does, but you must put on a calm temperate action, with a kind of careless smile, in contempt of fortune, as not being able with all her engines to batter down one piece of your estate, that your means may be thought invincible, never tell your money, nor what you have won, nor what you have lost: if a question be made: your answer must be, what I have lost, I have lost, what I have won, I have won, a close heart and free hand, makes a man admired, a testern or a shilling to a servant that brings you a glass of beer, binds his hands to his lips, you shall have more service of him, than his master, he will be more humble to you, than a cheater before a magistrate.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Gervase, give me thy hand, I think thou hast more wit than I that am thy master, and for this speech only, I do here create thee my steward: I do long methinks to be at an ordinary, to smile at fortune, and to be bountiful: Gervase about your business good Gervase, whilst I go and meditate upon a gentlemanlike behaviour, I have an excellent gate already Gervase, have I not?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Hercules himself sir, had never a better gate.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: But dispatch Gervase, the satin and the velvet must be thought upon, and the tu quoque must not be forgotten: for whensoever I give arms, that shall be my motto. Exit bub.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
What a fortune had I thrown upon me, when I preferred myself into this fellow's service! indeed I serve myself, and not him, for this gold here is mine own truly purchased: he has credit, and shall run ith' books for't, I'll carry things so cunningly, that he shall not be able to look into my actions, my mortgage I have already got into my hands: the rent he shall enjoy a while, till his riot constrain him to sell it, which I will purchase with his own money, I must cheat a little, I have been cheated upon, therefore I hope
the world will a little the better excuse me, what his uncle craftily got from me, I will knavishly recover of him, to come by it, I must vary shapes, and my first shift shall be in satin:
sp.l: Proteus propitious be to my disguise,
And I shall prosper in my enterprise. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Spendall, pursevet, and a boy with rackets.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A rubber sirrah.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You shall sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: And bid those two men you said would speak with me, come in.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will sir. Exit boy.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Did I not play this set will?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Excellent well by Phaeton, by Erebus, it went as if it had cut the line.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: God bless you sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Master blank! welcome.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Here's the gentleman's man sir has brought the money.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Will't please you tell sir?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Have you the bond ready master blank?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: 'Tis well, pursenet, help to tell — 10.11.22. What time have you given?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: The thirteenth of the next month.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: 'Tis well, here's light gold.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: 'Twill be the less troublesome to carry.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You say well sir, how much hast thou told?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: In gold and silver here is twenty pounds.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: 'Tis right m. Spendall, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I'll take your warrant sir, and tell no further, come let me see the condition of this obligation.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.l: A man may win from him that cares not for't,
This royal Caesar doth regard no cash,
Has thrown away as much in ducks and drakes,
As would have bought some 50000 capons.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: 'Tis very well; so, lend me your pen.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.l: This is the captain of brave citizens,
The Agamemnon of all merry Greeks,
A Stukely or a Shirley for his spirit,
Bounty and royalty to men at arms.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: You give this as your deed.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Ma●y do I sir.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Pleaseth this gentleman to be a witness.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Yes marry shall he, pursenet, your hand.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.l: My hand is at thy service, noble Brutus.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: There's for your kindness master blank.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: For your pains.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I'll take my leave of you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: What, must you be gone too, master blank?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Yes indeed sir, I must to the exchange.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Farewell to both, pursenet,
Take that twenty pounds, and give it mistress Sweatma●● ▪
Bid her pay her landlord and apothecary,
And let her butcher and her baker stay,
They're honest men, and I'll take order with them.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: The butcher and the baker then shall stay.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: They must till I am somewhat stronger pursed.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: If this be all, I have my errand perfect. Exit purs.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Here sirrah, here's for balls, there's for yourself.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Commend me to your mistress. Exit Spend.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I will sir; in good faith 'tis the liberallest gentleman that comes into our court, why he cares no more for a shilling than I do for a box o'th ear, God bless him. Exit.

div.stage: Enter stains gallant, Longfield and a servant.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Sirrah, what o'clock is't?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Past ten sir.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Here will not be a gallant seen this hour.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Within this quarter sir, and less, they meet here as soon as at any ordinary i'th town.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Hast any tobacco?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Fill.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Why thou reportest miracles, things not to be believed: I protest to thee, hadst thou not unripped thyself to me, I should never have known thee.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I tell you true sir, I was so far gone, that desperation knocked at mine elbow, and whispered news to me out of Barbary.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Well, I'm glad so good an occasion stayed thee at home,
And mayest thou prosper in thy project, and go on,
With best success of thy invention.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: False dice say amen, for that's my induction,
I do mean to cheat today without respect of persons:
When sawest thou will rash?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: This morning at his chamber, hell be here.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why then do thou give him my name and character, for my aim is wholly at my worshipful master.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Nay thou shalt take another into him, one that laughs out his life in this ordinary, thanks any man that wins his money; all the while his money is losing, he swears by the cross of this silver, and when it is gone, he changeth it to the hilts of his sword.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: He'll be an excellent coach-horse for my captain.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Save you gallants, save you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: How think ye now? have I not carved him out to you?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Thou'st lighted me into his heart, I see him thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Ninnihammer.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Take my cloak and rapier also: I think it be early gentlemen, what time do you take it to be?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Inclining to eleven sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Inclining! A good word; I would it were inclining to twelve, for by my stomach it should be high noon: but what shall we do gallants? shall we to cards, till our company come?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Please you sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Harry. fetch sir cards, methinks 'tis an unseemly fight to see gentlemen stand idle, please you to impart your smoke.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Very willingly sir.

sp.speaker: S●at
sp.p: In good faith a pipe of excellent vapour.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: The best the house yields.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Had you it in the house? I had thought it had been your own: 'tis not so good now as I took it to be: come gentlemen, what's your game?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why gleek, that's your only game.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Gleek let it be, for I am persuaded I shall gleek some of you; cut sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What play we, twelve pence gleek.

sp.speaker: Scat ▪
sp.p: Twelve pence, a crown; uds foot I will not spoil my memory for twelve pence.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Honour.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: What is't, hearts?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: The King, what say you?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: You must speak sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Why I bid thirteen.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Fourteen.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Fifteen.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Sixteen.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Sixteen, seventeen.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: You shall have't for me.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Eighteen.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Take it to you sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Udslid I'll not be outbraved.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I vie it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I'll none of it.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Give me a mournival of aces, and a gleek of Queens.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And me a gleek of knaves.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Udslid, I am gleeked this time. Enter Will rash.

sp.speaker: Stay.
sp.p: Play.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Equal fortunes befall you gallants.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Will rash, well, I pray see what a vile game I have

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: What's your game, gleek?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Yes faith, gleek, and I have not one court card, but the knave of clubs.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Thou hast a wild hand indeed: thy small cards show like a troop of rebels, and the knave of clubs their chief leader.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: And so they do as God save me, by the cross of this silver he says true. Enter Spendall.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Pray, play sir:

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Honour.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: How go the stocks gentlemen, what's won or lost?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: This is the first game.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Yes this is the first game, but by the cross of this silver here's all of five pounds.

sp.speaker: Spend,
sp.p: Good day to you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Francke, welcome by this hand, how dost lad?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: And how does thy wench i'faith.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Why fat and plump
Like thy geldings: thou givest them both good provender
It seems, go to, thou art one of the maddest wags,
Of a citizen ith' town, the whole company talks of thee already.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Talk, why let 'em talk, udsfoot I pay scot and lot, and all manner of duties else, as well as the best of 'em: it may be they understand I keep a whore, a horse, and a kennel of hounds, what's that to them? no man's purse opens for't but mine own; and so long, my hounds shall eat flesh, my horse bread, and my whore wear velvet.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why there spoke a courageous boy.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Uds'foot, shall I be confined all the days of my life to walk under a penthouse? no, I'll take my pleasure whiles my youth affords it.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: By the cross of these hilts, I'll never play at gleek again, whilst I have a nose on my face,
I smell the knavery of the game.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Why what's the matter? who has lost?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Marry that have I, by the hilts of my sword, I have lost forty crowns, in as small time almost, as while a man might tell it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Change your game for dice,
We are a full number for novum.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: With all my heart, where's m. ambush the broker Ninnihammer?

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Go to m. ambush, and bid him send me twenty marks upon this diamond. Enter Bubble.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Look you (To make us the merrier) who comes here.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: A fresh gamester, m. bubble, God save you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Tu quoque sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: God save you master bubble.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Tu quoque.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Save you sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Et tu quoque.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Good master Bubleb

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Et tu quoque.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Is your name master bubble?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Master bubble is my name, sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: God save you sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Et tu quoque.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: I would be better acquainted with you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: And I with you.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Pray let us salute again.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: With all my heart sir.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Behold yonder the oak and the ivy how they embrace.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Excellent acquaintance, they shall be the gemini.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Shall I desire your name sir?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Master Scattergood.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Of the Scattergood's of London?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: No indeed sir, of the Scattergood's of Hampshire.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Good master Scattergood.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Come gentlemen, here's dice.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Please you advance to the table?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Pray will you go?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I will go sir over the whole world for your sake, but in courtesy I will not budge a foot. Enter Ninnihammer.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.l: Here is the cash you sent me for, and master rash,
Here is a letter from one of your sisters ▪

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I have the dice, set gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: From which sister?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: From the madcap, I know by the hand.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: For me, six.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: And six that.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Nine; 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, and 8: eighteen shillings.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: What's yours sir?

sp.speaker: S●a●.
sp.p: Mine's a baker's dozen: master bubble tell your money.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: In good faith I am but a simple gamester, and do not know what to do.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Why you must tell your money, and he'll pay you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: My money! I do know how much my money is, but he shall not pay me, I have a better conscience than so: what for throwing the dice twice, i'faith he should have but a hard bargain of it.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Witty rascal, I must needs away.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why the lovers can not agree, thou shalt along with me, and know all.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: But first let me instruct thee in the condition of this gentleman, whom dost thou take him to be?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Nay, he's a stranger, I know him not.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: By this light but you do, if his beard were off, 'tis St●ined●.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: The devil it is as soon: and what's his purpose in this disguise?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Why cheating, do you not see how he plays upon his worshipful master, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: By my faith he draws apace.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A pox upon these dice, give's a fresh bale.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p:
Ha ha, the dice are not to be blamed, a man may perceive
this is no gentlemanly gamester, by his chasing: do you hear, my friend, fill me a glass of beer, and there's a shilling for your pains.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Your worship shall sir.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why how now Frank, what hast lost?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Fifteen pounds and onwards: is there never an honest fellow.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: What do you lack money sir?

sp.speaker: Sp●nd.
sp.p: Yes, canst furnish me?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Upon a sufficient pawn sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You know my shop, bid my man deliver you a piece of three pile velvet, and let me have as much money as you dare adventure upon't.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: You shall sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: A pox of this luck, it will not last ever:
Play sir, I'll set you.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Frank, better fortune befall thee: and gentlemen, I must take my leave, for I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Must you needs be gone?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Indeed I must.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Et tu quoque?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes truly.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: At your discretion's gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Farewell. Exeunt rash and Long.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Cry you mercy sir, I am chanced with you all gentlemen: here I have 7, here 7, and here 10.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: 'Tis right sir, and ten that.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: And nine that.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Two fives at all. Draws all.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: One and five that.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: V●nh, and can a suit of satin cheat so grossly? By this light there's naught on one die but fives and sixes, I must not be thus gulled.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Come master Spendall, set.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No sir, I have done.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Why then let us all leave, for I think dinner's near ready.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Your meat's upon the table.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: On the table! come gentlemen, we do our stomachs wrong: m. bubble, what have you lost?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: That's no matter, what I have lost, I have lost; nor can I choose but smile at the foolishness of the dice.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I am but your steward gentlemen, for after dinner I may restore it again.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: M. Scattergood, will you walk in?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: I'll wait upon you sir, come gentlemen, will you follow? Exit: manent Spendall and Staines.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Yes sir, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Spe●.
sp.p: Hear you sir, a word.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Ten if you please.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I have lost fifteen pounds.

sp.speaker: Sta
sp.p: And I have found it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: You say right, found it you have indeed,
But never won it: do you know this die?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: You seem a gentleman, and you may perceive.
I have some respect unto your credit,
To take you thus aside, will you restore
What you ha' drawn from me unlawfully?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Sirrah, by your outside you seem a citizen,
Whose coxcomb, I were apt enough to break,
But for the law; go you're a prating Jack,
Nor 'Is't your hopes, of crying out for clubs,
Can save you from my chastisement, if once
You shall but dare to utter this again.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You lie, you dare pot.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Lie! nay villain, now thou tempest me to thy death.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: So 't, you must buy it dearer,
The best blood flows within you is the price.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Dar'st thou resist, thou art no citizen.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I am a citizen.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Say thou art a gentleman, and I am satisfied,
For then I know thou'lt answer me in field.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: I'll say directly what I am, a citizen,
and I will meet thee in the field as fairly
As the best gentleman that wears a sword.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I accept it, the meeting place.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Beyond the maze in Tuttle.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: What weapon?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Single rapier.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: The time.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: The hour.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Twixt nine and ten.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: 'Tis good, I shall expect you, farewell. Ex. omnes.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Farewell sir.

div.stage: Enter Will rash, Long-field, and Joyce.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why I commend thee girl, thou speak'st as thou thinkst, thy tongue and thy heart are relatives, and thou wert not my sister, I should at this time fall in love with thee.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: You should not need, for and you were not my brother, I should fall in love with you, for I love a proper man with my heart, and so does all the sex of us, let my sister dissemble never so much, I am out of charity with these nice and squeamish tricks, we were born for men, and men for us, and we must together.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: This same plain dealing is a jewel in thee.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: And let me enjoy that jewel, for I love plain dealing with my heart.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Thou'rt a good wench i'faith, I should never be ashamed to call thee sister, though thou shouldst marry a broomeman: but your lover methinks is over tedious.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: No, look ye sir, could you wish a man to come better upon his cue, let us withdraw.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Close, close, for the prosecution of the plot, wench,
See he prepares.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.l: The sun is yet wrapped in Aurora's arms,
And lulled with her delight, forgets his creatures:
awake thou god of heat,
I call thee up, and task thee for thy slowness;
Point all thy beams through yonder flaring glass,
And raise a beauty brighter than thy self;Music.
Musicians, give to each instrument a tongue,
To breathe sweet music in the ears of her
To whom I send it as a messenger. Enter Gartred aloft.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Sir, your music is so good, that I must say I like it; but the bringer so ill welcome, that I could be content to lose it: if you played for money, there 'tis; if for love, here's none; if for goodwill, I thank you, and when you will you may be gone,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Leave me not entranced: sing not my death,
Thy voice is able to make satires tame,
And call rough winds to her obedience.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Sir, sir, our ears itch not for flattery, here you besiege my window, that I dare not put forth myself to take the gentle air, but you are in the fields, and volley out your woes, your plaints, your loves, your injuries.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Since you have heard, and know them, give redress, true beauty never yet was merciless.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Sir, rest thus satisfied, my mind was never woman, never altered, nor shall it now begin: so fare you well. Exis gart.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, she plays the terrible tyrannising Tamberlaine over him, this it is to turn Turk, from a most absolute complete gentleman, to a most absurd ridiculous and fond lover.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: O, when a woman knows the power and authority of her eye.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: Fie upon her, she's good for nothing then, no more than a jade that knows his own strength: the window is clasped, now brother, pursue your project, and deliver your friend from the tyranny of my domineering sister.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Do you hear, you drunkard in love, come in to
us and be ruled, you would little think, that the wench that talked so scuruily out of the window there, is more enamoured on thee than thou on her: nay, look you now, see if he turn not away slighting our good council: I am no christian if she do not sigh, whine, and grow sick for thee: look you sir, I will bring you in good witness against her.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: Sir, you're my brothers friend, and I'll be plain with you, you do not take the course to win my sister, but indirectly go about the bush: you come and fiddle here, and keep a coil in verse: hold off your hat, and beg to kiss her hand, which makes her proud. But to be short, in two lines thus it is:
sp.l: Who most doth love, must seem most to neglect it,
For those that show most love, are least respected.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: A good observation by my faith.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Well this instruction comes too late now,
Stand you close, and let me prosecute my invention,
Sister, oh sister, wake, arise sister.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: How now brother, why call you with such terror?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: How can you sleep so sound, and hear such groans,
So horrid and so tedious to the ear,
That I was frighted hither by the sound?
O sister, here lies a gentleman that loved you too dear,
And himself too ill, as by his death appears,
I can report no further without tears;
Assist me now.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: When he came first, death startled in his eyes,
His hand had not forsook the dagger hilt,
But still he gave it strength, as if he feared
He had not sent it home unto his heart.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Enough, enough,
If you will have me live, give him no name,
Suspicion tells me 'tis my Geraldine:
But be it whom it will, I'll come to him,
to suffer death as resolute as he. Exit Gart.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Did not I tell you 'twould take, down sir down.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I guess what you'd have me do.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: O for a little blood to besprinkle him.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: No matter for blood, I'll not suffer her to come near him, till the plot have ta'en his full height.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: A scarf o'er my face, left I betray myself.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Here, here, lie still, she comes,
Now Mercury, be propitious.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Where lies this spectacle of blood?
This tragic scene.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Yonder lies Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: O let me see him with his face of death!
Why do you stay me from my Geraldine?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Because, unworthy as thou art, thou shalt not see
The man now dead, whom living thou didst scorn,
The worst part that he had, deserved thy best,
But yet contemned, deluded, mocked, despised by you,
Unfit for aught but for the general mark
Which you were made for, man's creation.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Burst not my heart before I see my love,
Brother, upon my knees I beg your leave,
That I may see the wound of Geraldine,
I will embalm his body with my tears,
And carry him unto his sepulchre,
From whence I'll never rise, but be interred
In the same dust he shall be buried in.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I do protest she draws sad tears from me,
I pray thee let her see her Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Brother, if e'er you loved me as a sister,
Deprive me not the sight of Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Well, I am contented you shall touch his lips,
But neither see his face nor yet his wound,

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Not see his face?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Nay, I have sworn it to the contrary:
Nay, hark you further yet.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: What now?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: But one kiss, no more.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Why then no more.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Marry this liberty I'll give you,
If you intend to make my speech of repentance
Over him, I am content, so it be short.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: What you command is law, and I obey.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.l: Peace, give ear to the passion.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Before I touch thy body, I implore
Thy discontented ghost to be appeased:
Send not unto me till I come myself:
Then shalt thou know how much I honoured thee.
O see the colour of his coral lip!
Which in despite of death lives full and fresh,
As when he was the beauty of his sex:
'Twere sin worthy the worst of plagues to leave thee:
Not all the strength and policy of man
Shall snatch me from thy bosom.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Look, look, I think she'll ravish him.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Why how now sister?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Shall we have both one grave? here I am chained,
Thunder nor earthquakes shall shake me off.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: No? I'll try that, come dead man, awake, up with your bag and baggage, and let's have no more fooling.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: And lives my Geraldine?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Live? faith I,
Why should he not? he was never dead,
That I know on.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It is no wonder Geraldine should live,
Though he had emptied all his vital spirits,
The lute of Orpheus spoke not half so sweet,
When he descended to th'infernal vaults,
To fetch again his fair Eurydice,
As did thy sweet voice to Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: I'll exercise that voice, since it doth please
My better self, my constant Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.l: Why so la, here's an end of an old song,
Why could not this have been done before
I pray?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: O you're a goodly sister, this is your plot:
Well, I shall live one day to requite you.

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: Spare me not, for wheresoever I set my affection, although it be upon a collier, if I fall back, unless it be in the right kind, bind me to a stake, and let me be burned to death with charcoal.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Well, thou art a mad wench, and there's no more to be done at this time, but as we brought you together, so to part you, you must not lie at rack and manger: there be those within, that will forbid the banes, time must shake good fortune by the hand, before you two must be great, specially you sister; come leave swearing.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Must we then part?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Must you part? why how think you? udsfoote, I do think we shall have as much to do to get her from him, as we had to bring her to him: this love of women is of a strange quality, and has more tricks than a juggler.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: But this, and then farewell.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Thy company is heaven, thy absence hell.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Lord who'd think it?

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: Come wench. Exeunt omnes.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: This ground is firm and even, I'll go no further.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: This be the place then, and prepare you sir,
You shall have fair play for your life of me,
For look sir, I'll be open breasted to you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Shame light on him that thinks his safety lieth in a
French doublet.
Nay I would strip myself, would comeliness
give sufferance to the deed, and fight with thee,
As naked as a Mauritanian Moor.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Give me thy hand, by my heart I love thee,
Thou art the highest spirited citizen,
That ever Guildhall took notice of.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Talk not what I am, until you have tried me.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Come on sir. They fight.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Now sir, your life is mine.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Why then take it, for I'll not beg it of thee.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Nobly resolved, I love thee for those words,
Here take thy arms again, and if thy malice
Have spent itself like mine, then let us part
More friendly than we met at first encounter.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Sir, I accept this gift of you, but not your friendship,
Until I shall recover't with my honour.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Will you fight again then?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Faith thou dost well then, justly to whip my folly.
But come sir.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Hold, you're hurt I take it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Hurt! where? 'zounds I feel it not.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: You bleed I am sure.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: 'Sblood, I think you wear a cat's claw upon your
Rapier's point,
I am scratched indeed, but small as 'tis,
I must have blood for blood.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: You're bent to kill I see.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: No by my hopes, if I can scape that sin,
And keep my good name, I'll never offer't.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Well sir, your worst.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: We both bleed now I take it,
And if the motion may be equal thought,
To part with clasped hands: I shall first subscribe.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: It were unmanliness in me to refuse
The safety of us both, my hand shall never fall
From such a charitable motion.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Then join we both, and here our malice ends,
Though foes we came to'th field, we'll depart friends. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter sir Lyonell and a servant.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Come, come, follow me knave, follow me, I have the best nose ith' house, I think, either we shall have rainy weather, or the vaults unstopped: sirrah, go see, I would not have my guess smell out any such inconvenience: do you hear sirrah Simon?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Bid the kitchenmaid scour the sink, and make clean her backside, for the wind lies just upon't.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: And bid Anthony put on his white fustian doublet, for he must wait today: it doth me so much good to stir and talk, to place this, and displace that, that I shall need no apothecaries prescriptions, I have sent my daughter this morning as far as Pimliko to fetch a draught of Derby ale, that it may fetch a colour in her cheeks, the puling harlotry looks so pale, and it is all for want of a man, for so their mother would say, God rest her soul, before she died. Exit servant.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Sir, the gentlemen are come already.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: How knave, the gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Yes sir, yonder they are.

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.p: God's precious, we are too tardy, let one be sent presently to meet the girls, and hasten their coming home quickly: how dost thou stand dreaming? Gentlemen, I see you love me, you are careful of your hour; you may be deceived in your cheer, but not in your welcome.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Thanks, and tu quoque is a word for all.

sp.speaker: Scatterg.
sp.p: A pretty concise room: sir Lyonell, where are your daughters?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: They are at your service sir, and forth coming.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: God's will Gervase! how shall I behave myself to the gentlewomen?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why advance yourself towards them, with a comely step, and in your salute, be careful you strike not too high, nor too low, and afterwards for your discourse, your tu quoque will bear you out.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Nay, and that be all, I care not, for I'll set a good face on't, that's flat: and for my nether parts, let them speak for themselves: here's a leg, and ever a baker in England show me a better, I'll give him mine for nothing.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: O that's a special thing that I must caution you of.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What sweet Gervase?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why for commending yourself; never whilst you line commend yourself: and than you shall have the ladies themselves commend you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I would they would else.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why they will I'll assure you sir, and the more vilely you speak of yourself, the more will they strive to collaud you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Let me alone to dispraise myself,
I'll make myself the arrantest coxcomb within a whole
Country.

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.l: Here come the Gipsies, the sunburned girls,
Whose beauties will not utter them alone,
They must have bags although my credit crack for't.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Is this the eldest sir?

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.l: Yes marry is she sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: I'll kiss the youngest first, because she likes me best.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: Marry sir, and whilst you are there, I'll be here:
Oh delicious touch! I think in conscience
Her lips are lined quite through with Orange tawny velvet.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: They kiss exceeding well, I do not think but they have been brought up to't, I will begin to her like a gentleman in a set speech: fair lady, shall I speak a word with you?

sp.speaker: Joyce.
sp.p: With me sir?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: With you lady, — this way, — a little more, —
So now 'tis well, umh —
Even as a drummer, — or a pewterer.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Which of the two no matter,
For one beats on a drum, tother a platter.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: In good faith sweet lady you say true ▪
But pray mark me further, I will begin again.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: I pray sir do.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Even as a drummer, as I said before, —
Or as a pewterer.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Very good sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Do — do — do.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: What do they do?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: By my troth lady, I do not know: for to say truth, I am a kind of an ass.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: How sir, an ass?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Yes indeed lady.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Nay that you are not.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: So God ha me, I am lady: you never saw an arranter ass in your life.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Why here's a gentleman your friend, will not say so.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Y faith but he shall: how say you sir,
Am not I an ass?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Yes by my troth lady is he: why I'll say any thing my brother bubble says.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Is this the man my father choose for me, to make a husband of? O God, how blind are parents in our loves: so they have wealth, they care not to what things they marry us.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Pray look upon me lady.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: So I do sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I but look upon me well, and tell me if you ever saw any man look so scurvily, as I do?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: The fellow sure is frantic.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: You do not mark me?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Yes indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Ay, but look upon me well:
Did you ever see a worse timbered leg?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: By my faith 'tis a pretty four square leg.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: I but your four square legs are none of the best.
Oh! Jarvis, Jarvis.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Excellent well sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What say you now to me lady, can you find ere a good inch about me?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Yes that I can sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Find it, and take it sweet lady:
There I think I bobbed her, Jarvis?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Well sir, disparage not yourself so: for if you were
The man you'd make yourself; yet out of your
Behaviour and discourse, I could find cause enough
To love you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Augh! now she comes to me: my behaviour? alas, alas, 'tis clownical; and my discourse is very bald, bald: you shall not hear me break a good jest in a twelvemonth .

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: No sir? why now you break a good jest.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: No, I want the boon joure, and the tu quoques,
Which yonder gentleman has: there's a bob for him too:
There's a gentleman, and you talk of a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Who he? he's a coxcomb indeed.

sp.speaker: Bub.
